nodes.text: US heritage/ancestry of US residents has nothing to do with 'numerous other origin stories of non-biblical religions' so they shouldn't be taught publicly in US scientific origins speculations. Only the ID/evolution controversy should be taught. My reasons for it are detailed here. If you want to say I was 'wrong' because I 'lost', then you go right ahead and say it. You could even call me a 'liberal' while you're at it.

So what are the Native Americans (the actual residents) - chopped liver? If anything it should be their creation stories of the Sioux, etc. that should be taught over that of Christians (the invaders and slaughterers of the indigineous people).

Substantially, that logic dictates that much of radioactivity shouldn't be taught as we didn't come up with it. If we decided based on heritage what we should teach in science, we'd be leaving out vast amounts of chemistry, biology and physic from science.
And once you build one straw man, you tend to substantially build even bigger ones.
If anything it should be their creation stories of the Sioux, etc. that should be taught over that of Christians (the invaders and slaughterers of the indigineous people).
Oh, we could let them in I guess. How much room would it take up in a textbook, two pages maybe?
